The synthesis of high-value organic nitrogen compounds from renewable chitin biomass presents significant environmental advantages by reducing reliance on fossil resources. Among these compounds, 3-acetamido-5-acetylfuran (3A5AF) has emerged as a versatile nitrogen-containing platform molecule, attracting extensive research attention. However, existing studies indicate that 3A5AF formation in polar aprotic solvents (e.g., N, N-dimethylacetamide, DMA) typically requires harsh conditions (>150 °C), likely due to limited catalyst and substrate solubility at lower temperatures. To address this challenge, this study employed anhydrous magnesium chloride (MgCl₂) as a catalyst—selected for its Cl⁻ supply capacity based on solubility tests—combined with ammonium salts as additives to establish a weakly acidic reaction environment. The catalytic system enabled efficient 3A5AF conversion under milder conditions, achieving a remarkable yield of 60.3% at 140 °C. This research provides a low-energy, economic and easy-to-industrialize technological path for the preparation of nitrogen-containing fine chemicals from chitin biomass. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 3A5AF Chitin biomass Chloride salts Solubility Solubilization promotion Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The extensive exploitation and utilization of fossil energy by humans have not only resulted in resource depletion but have also given rise to an array of severe ecological and environmental issues [1,2]. Consequently, the development and utilization of renewable energy sources have garnered considerable international attention [3]. Biomass, characterized by its ecological friendliness and multifunctionality, stands out as a promising renewable resource. These attributes endow it with substantial potential for application in energy, materials, and chemical production [4–6]. Among the various biomass resources, cellulose and chitin are two prominent natural resources on Earth [7,8]. Both can be converted into a multitude of nitrogen- and oxygen-containing chemicals through diverse conversion pathways [9,10]. However, chitin biomass possesses a unique advantage over cellulose due to its high nitrogen content, attributed to the amide bond (-CONH-) within its molecular structure [11]. This nitrogen-rich characteristic provides chitin with a natural edge in the preparation of nitrogen-containing compounds, rendering it more environmentally friendly compared to cellulose, as it eliminates the need for additional nitrogen fixation through the Haber-Bosch process [12,13]. Among the diverse organic nitrogen compounds derived from chitin biomass, 3A5AF has emerged as a promising multifunctional platform compound. Its naturally occurring active heterocyclic ring imparts the ability to undergo chemical reactions with a broad spectrum of substances, yielding derivatives of various chemicals, including amides, alcohols, and amino furans [14,15]. However, the inherent high crystallinity of chitin contributes to its robust thermal stability and limited solubility, posing significant challenges in directly converting it to 3A5AF. This necessitates the application of both chemical and physical processing methods to facilitate the conversion [16,17]. Conversely, the monomeric unit of chitin, known as N-acetylglucosamine (NAG), exhibits a relatively weaker hydrogen bonding network between its molecular chains and possesses enhanced chemical reactivity. These attributes render NAG more susceptible to conversion into 3A5AF via chemical catalysis, thereby presenting a viable alternative pathway to produce this multifunctional platform compound. In recent years, researchers have conducted extensive investigations into the catalytic conversion of NAG to 3A5AF by exploring the synergistic effects between key factors such as catalysts, solvents, temperature, and time. Additionally, they have explored the potential catalytic mechanisms associated with various catalysts. For the catalytic conversion of NAG, the first problem to be solved is its solubility in solvents, and some strong polar solvents such as N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) are preferred as solvents to promote the solubilization of NAG and facilitate its ring-opening reaction. However, researchers have mostly concluded that the formation of 3A5AF in these strongly polar solvents typically necessitates higher temperatures (Table 1 ), Wang et, al. achieved a 52.61 % yield of 3A5AF at 200 °C in DMA using glycine chloride ( [Gly]Cl) ionic liquid and calcium chloride (CaCl2) as catalysts [18]. Yang et, al. Anhydrous lithium chloride (LiCl) in NMP or DMA was used to obtain about 60 % yield, but also at temperatures as high as 200 °C [19]. Du et, al. synthesized pyrazine hydrochloride ionic liquid ( [Pyz]Cl) in DMA with the addition of boric acid (B(OH)3) and CaCl2 to obtain 69 % 3A5AF yield at temperatures as high as 190 °C [20]. Currently, only a limited number of studies have reported catalytic systems to produce 3A5AF at lower temperatures, Zhao et, al. obtained a 39.2 % yield of 3A5AF in DMA using a ternary eutectic solvent of choline chloride (ChCl)/glycerol/B(OH)3 at 140 °C, which is not only cumbersome but also low yielding [21]. Padovan et,al. obtained a 39.2 % yield of 3A5AF in DMF using Aluminum trichloride hexahydrate (AlCl3⋅6H2O) as a catalyst in DMF gave 3A5AF in only 30 % yield at 120 °C [22], and they speculated that the decreased solubility of the chloride salts in the solvent due to the lower temperatures significantly reduced the chloride ion concentration in the solution, thereby affecting catalytic performance. In addition, Ji et, al. found that NH4SCN as a catalyst could significantly enhance the solvation environment of NAG and effectively solve the problem of its solubilization in γ-valerolactone (GVL) [23], which led to the efficient dehydration of NAG to produce 3A5AF in yields of more than 70 % at a lower temperature of 140 °C. However, this system employed hydrochloric acid (HCl), a strongly corrosive acid, as an additive. The strongly acidic environment can lead to side reactions within the system. Moreover, the use of HCl not only increases the difficulty and cost of recycling but is also environmentally unfriendly. Based on these findings, we hypothesize that the solubility of the catalyst and the substrate NAG in the system under low-temperature conditions may be the two crucial factors influencing the catalytic conversion of NAG. Good solubility of both the catalyst and the substrate could enhance their contact, enabling the catalytic conversion reaction to occur efficiently. Therefore, our objective is to develop a simple catalytic system with excellent catalyst solubility and a significant solubility-promoting effect. This catalytic system is expected to exhibit a notable solubility-enhancing effect, enabling the efficient production of 3A5AF at low temperatures. In this study, the solubility of chloride salts in organic solvents and their solubilization-enhancing effect on NAG were investigated. As a result, MgCl2 was selected as the catalyst, while ammonium salt was utilized as an additive to establish a weakly acidic reaction environment. Among various ammonium salts, NH4Cl exhibited the most favourable effect. The yield of 3A5AF was monitored at moderate temperatures, and following the optimization of reaction conditions, a maximum yield of 60 % was achieved at 140 °C (Fig. 1 c). The isolation and purification of 3A5AF produced in this system were conducted through low-temperature crystallization. Ultimately, Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS) and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) techniques were employed to identify two potential key intermediates and propose plausible reaction pathways. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Materials N-acetylglucosamine (NAG, 98 %) was purchased from Aladdin Reagent, USA. Anhydrous magnesium chloride (MgCl2, AR grade) was purchased from Tianjin Beichen Fangzheng Reagent Factory. Ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, AR grade), anhydrous lithium chloride (LiCl, AR grade), anhydrous calcium chloride (CaCl2, AR grade), anhydrous ferric trichloride (FeCl3, AR grade), anhydrous aluminum trichloride (AlCl3, AR grade) were purchased from Sahn Chemical Technology (Shanghai) Co. Manganese chloride tetrahydrate (MnCl2⋅4H2O, AR grade), zinc chloride (ZnCl2, AR grade), barium chloride dihydrate (BaCl2⋅2H2O, AR grade), were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Sodium chloride (NaCl, AR grade), potassium chloride (KCl, AR grade), ammonium oxalate ((NH4)2C2O4, AR grade), ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3, AR grade), ammonium carbonate ((NH4)2CO3, AR grade), ammonium acetate (NH4HCO2, AR grade), ammonium thiocyanate (NH4SCN, AR grade), ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4, AR grade), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, AR grade), N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP, AR grade), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR grade), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, AR grade), γ-valerolactone (GVL, AR grade), methanol (AR grade), acetonitrile (HPLC grade), and ethyl acetate (AR grade) were purchased from Shanghai McLean Biochemistry and Technology Co. Ltd. All the reagents were not further purified. 2.2 Conversion of NAG to 3A5AF The conversion of NAG to 3A5AF was carried out in tubular thick-walled pressure-resistant tubes, usually, different molarities of NAG (50–175 mM) and catalysts with different molar ratios (50 mol %-500 mol %) were added to the pressure-resistant tubes followed by the addition of 4 mL of solvents (DMA, DMF, NMP, DMSO, and GVL) at The reaction solution was magnetically stirred at different reaction temperatures, quenched with ice water after the specified reaction time and fixed with methanol and filtered (using 0.22 μm PTFE microporous filters), and finally quantitatively analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). 2.3 Solubility and solubilization promotion test of several chlorine salts The solubility of several chlorine salts in DMA (4 mL) was tested to screen out the chlorine salts with better solubility, to make the test results more accurate, the solution should be saturated and the chlorine salts added were in excess (400 mg), stirred for 3 min at 140 °C, filtered to get the undissolved solids, washed with ethanol for several times and then dried in an oven at 65 °C for 24 h, and finally weighed to calculate their solubility. Finally, the solubility was calculated by weighing. For the solubilizing effect test, 100 mg of chlorine salt was added, and then an excess of NAG (400 mg) was added after complete dissolution, and the solubilizing effect of chlorine salt was evaluated by calculating the solubility of NAG. The solubility was calculated by the following formula: S o l u b i l i t y ( w t % ) = ( i n i t i a l N A G ( m g ) − r e m a i n i n g s o l i d s ( m g ) ) / i n i t i a l N A G ( m g ) × 100 % 2.4 Quantitative analysis, separation, and purification of 3A5AF The content of 3A5AF in the reaction solution was analyzed using Agilent 1200HPLC with a reversed-phase chromatographic column of AQ-C18 5 μm (4.6*250 nm), the eluent was acetonitrile/water (20 %/80 %) at a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min, the column temperature was maintained at 35 °C, the run time was 25 min, and the UV–visible detector was set at 230 nm. The concentration of 3A5AF was quantified according to the 3A5AF standard curve (Fig. S1). The formula for the yield of 3A5AF was calculated as follows: 3 A 5 A F y i e l d % = ( m o l e s o f 3 A 5 A F ) / ( m o l e s o f N A G ) × 100 % For the isolation and purification of 3A5AF, the reaction solution was extracted by filtration and added to an equal volume of water, then extracted with ethyl acetate for several times, and the collected organic phase was concentrated by rotary evaporation to obtain the crude product, which was fully dissolved with methanol and then adsorbed and decolorized with activated carbon, and the filtrate obtained by filtration was then concentrated by rotary evaporation, and the concentrated liquid was slowly added to the pre-cooled water by dropping it into the pre-cooled water, and the mixture was placed in a static position at 4 °C overnight, which gave the crystals of 3A5AF. Crystals were obtained, and their structure could be confirmed by 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra. 2.5 Recycling of catalysts and solvents After reaction under optimal reaction conditions, the solid impurities were removed by filtration. An equal volume of water (4 mL) was added to the reaction solution and mixed thoroughly, then extracted with ethyl acetate several times, and the mixture was layered, with the upper organic phase being a solution with 3A5AF as the main product. The yield of 3A5AF was calculated for each time after the organic phase mixture was fixed with methanol and quantitatively analyzed. The lower layer is a mixture of water and DMA containing the catalyst, and the water can be removed by rotary evaporator. The resulting solution is supplemented with a small amount of DMA to maintain its volume at 4 mL, and fresh NAG is added for the next round of new reactions, and the above process is repeated four times. 2.6 Reaction pathway investigation The possible intermediates and reaction pathways were hypothesized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and HPLC-MS spectra. Specific experimental procedures: at a specific moment, 0.1 mL of reaction solution with different reaction times and reaction temperatures were taken and 0.6 mL of DMSO-d6 was added to completely dissolve the reaction solution for NMR detection; 0.1 mL of reaction solution with different reaction times were diluted with methanol and then subjected to HPLC-MS analysis using an Agilent 1290II-6460 Triple Quadruple Stage Rod LC/MS system with a positive, negative ion mode ESI-MS equipped with a Waters, BEH-C18, 1.7 μm (2.1 × 100 mm), mobile phase 0.1 % formic acid and acetonitrile at a flow rate of 0.25 mL/min, and a column temperature of 40 °C. The analytes were analyzed by HPLC-MS using an Agilent 1290II-6460 triple quadrupole LC-MS system with positive and negative ion modes. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Screening of catalysts, solvents, and additives It has been documented in the literature that certain Lewis’s acids exhibit efficacy in the dehydration of N-acetylglucosamine (NAG) to 3-acetamido-5-acetamidofuranose (3A5AF), with chloride salts being particularly noted for their effectiveness [24–26]. Consequently, common chloride salts were selected as the primary catalysts for this study. Previous research has demonstrated that excellent solubility facilitates the uniform dispersion of catalysts within the system, thereby enhancing their catalytic performance [27–29]. Therefore, the solubility of chloride salts emerged as a pivotal factor influencing their catalytic efficacy. Chloride salts possessing superior solubility are capable of better releasing and uniformly dispersing chloride ions within the solvent, ultimately leading to more effective catalysis. To screen for suitable chloride salts, the solubility of over a dozen chloride salts in various solvents (with DMA serving as an illustrative example) and their solubilization-promoting effects on NAG were examined. As depicted in (Fig. 1a), after stirring each catalyst at 140 °C for 3 min, MgCl2, MnCl2⋅4H2O, ZnCl2, and LiCl exhibited superior solubility. Notably, MgCl2 and MnCl2⋅4H2O were nearly fully dissolved, with solubilities of 99.8 % and 99.6 %, respectively. In contrast, BaCl2⋅2H2O, NaCl, and KCl displayed solubilities of less than 3 %. This disparity may be attributed to the smaller ionic radii and higher charge densities of Mg2+, Mn2+, Zn2+, and Li+ compared to Ba2+, Na+, and K+, enabling them to form stronger coordination bonds with solvents [30,31]. These findings underscore the importance of cations in the selection of chloride salt catalysts. Subsequently, the four chloride salts with superior solubility were chosen for further evaluation of their solubilization-promoting effects on NAG. As illustrated in (Fig. 1b) and Supplementary (Fig. S2), compared to the blank control group (lacking any catalysts), the solubility of NAG increased from 40.0 % to 52.0 % and 68.3 % upon the addition of ZnCl2 and MnCl2⋅4H2O, respectively. Similarly, the solubility of NAG rose to 99.5 % and 99.2 % after the incorporation of MgCl2 and LiCl, respectively, indicating a more pronounced solubilization-promoting effect. Additionally, the impact of different chloride salts on the yield of 3A5AF was investigated through reactions conducted at 140 °C for 30 min (Fig. 1c). The results revealed that the highest yield of 3A5AF, reaching 15.4 %, was achieved with the addition of MgCl2. Following comprehensive consideration, MgCl2 was ultimately selected as the primary catalyst for this study. For the selection of solvents, we conducted a series of experiments to assess the solubility characteristics of MgCl2 and the pro-dissolution effect of NAG in various solvents. Specifically, we tested the solubility of MgCl2 in DMF, DMSO, NMP, and GVL, as well as examined the dissolution behaviour of NAG in each of these solvents. As illustrated in (Fig. 2 a) and Supplementary (Figs. S3, S4 and S5), MgCl2 was almost completely dissolved in DMF and NMP at 140 °C, with a solubility of 99.8 %, and no crystals were precipitated after the temperature was returned to room temperature, and it was insoluble in GVL. It is noteworthy that MgCl2 crystals were observed when it was dissolved in DMSO at 140 °C and returned to room temperature, which is like the ‘hot solubilisation and cold precipitation’ of salts in water, suggesting that the solubility of MgCl2 in DMSO has a temperature dependence. Regarding the solubility of NAG, the solvents were ranked in descending order as follows: DMSO (100 %) > NMP (58.0 %) > DMF (44.3 %) > DMA (40.0 %) > GVL (2.4 %). Notably, upon the addition of MgCl2, the solubility of NAG underwent a significant change, with the new order being DMSO (100 %) > DMF (99.8 %) > DMA (99.5 %) > NMP (98.3 %) > GVL (2.7 %). The results showed that MgCl2 was effective in promoting solubility of NAG in DMA and DMF, increasing its solubility from 44.3 % and 40.0 % to more than 99 %, respectively. In particular, compared to several other organic solvents, DMSO exhibits superior solubility across a broad range of substances. This property stems from its polar-nonpolar amphiphilic structure, characterized by a substantial dipole moment and potent hydrogen bond acceptor capacity [32,33], and experiments have demonstrated that there is no exception for NAG, which is not able to be judged in the present experiments due to the fact that NAG is almost completely soluble in pure DMSO and in DMSO with MgCl2 added to it. the pro-dissolution effect of MgCl2 on NAG in DMSO. Furthermore, we investigated the impact of MgCl2 addition on the yield of 3A5AF when each solvent was subjected to a reaction at 140 °C for 60 min. The 3A5AF yield is shown in (Fig. 2b), Although DMSO demonstrates excellent solvating power, its efficacy in producing 3A5AF remains unsatisfactory. This limitation is attributed to its poor dehydrating properties. Specifically, the formation of a robust hydrogen-bonding network between DMSO and the substrate/intermediate species impedes subsequent dehydration steps, thereby hindering 3A5AF generation [34]. 3A5AF showed a relatively high yield of 16.8 % in DMA compared to 15.8 % and 13.5 % in NMP and DMF, respectively. Highest yield of 3A5AF in DMA. Moreover, compared with NMP and DMF, it has lower toxicity, volatility, easier degradation, lower risk of residue and more environmentally friendly [35]. After comprehensive consideration, we decided to use DMA as the best solvent in this catalytic system. The significance of additives in catalytic systems should not be underestimated. Previous research has demonstrated that the acidic environment of the system facilitates the dehydration of NAG [36], whereas exposure to a strongly acidic environment can result in the occurrence of undesirable side reactions. Consequently, our objective is to identify an additive that can establish a weakly acidic environment for use in conjunction with chloride salts to synergistically catalyse the dehydration reaction of NAG. It has been documented that Chen et al. employed NH4SCN to convert NAG to 3A5AF, achieving a yield of up to 56.66 % [37]. This finding suggests that NH4 + plays a pivotal role in the formation of 3A5AF. Similarly, Ji et al. utilized NH4SCN as a catalyst to attain an unprecedented yield of 75.3 % of 3A5AF in GVL [23]. The effectiveness of ammonium salts may be attributed to the Brønsted acidity of NH4 +, which causes it to dissociate in the solvent, releasing protons (H⁺). This dissociation results in a weakly acidic reaction solution environment [38], thereby enhancing the ring-opening and dehydration reactions of NAG more effectively. Building upon these observations, we considered the utilization of ammonium salts as additives. To this end, we screened several different ammonium salts in the presence of MgCl2 within the system, as illustrated in (Fig. 2c). The results revealed that after the introduction of NH4Cl, (NH4)2C2O4, and NH4NO3, and subsequent reaction at 140 °C for 30 min, the yields of 3A5AF were 44.1 %, 39.9 %, and 31.1 %, respectively. Conversely, the yields of 3A5AF with the addition of other ammonium salts were lower than 30 %. The optimal performance of NH4Cl may be due to its simultaneous release of NH4 + and Cl-. Consequently, NH4Cl was ultimately selected as the most effective additive. 3.2 Optimization of reaction conditions In chemo-catalytic reactions, catalyst dosage emerges as a pivotal parameter, exerting a direct influence on multiple facets of the reaction, encompassing reaction rate, selectivity, conversion, and catalyst efficiency [39,40]. Consequently, the initial focus was on optimizing the dosage of MgCl2 and NH4Cl, as illustrated in (Fig. 3 a). With the increase of MgCl2 dosage, the highest yield of 3A5AF was achieved at 400 mol %, reaching 20.8 %. However, further augmentation of the dosage to 500 mol % resulted in a decline in yield. Subsequently, NH4Cl was introduced onto a foundation of 200 mol % MgCl2 for additional refinement. As depicted in (Fig. 3b), the generation of 3A5AF was most advantageous when the NH4Cl dosage was set at 300 mol %, yielding 46.0 %. Notably, excessive catalyst addition did not favor the production of 3A5AF. Temperature and time are crucial determinants in catalysing reactions. Most of the previous studies have focused on high temperature conditions, and researchers have generally concluded that high temperature conditions are often required to produce 3A5AF in strongly polar solvents such as DMA. Conversely, the conversion of NAG to generate 3A5AF at lower temperatures remains understudied. Given this context, we monitored the synthesis of 3A5AF via HPLC following a 60-minute reaction period at mild temperatures ranging from 60 °C to 140 °C. The results, as presented in (Fig. S6), indicated that no 3A5AF was detectable at 60 °C, while a modest amount was produced at 80 °C, with a significant yield increase observed at 120 °C. Consequently, we opted to optimize the reaction temperature and time within a relatively mild temperature bracket of 120 °C to 150 °C. The outcomes, as shown in (Fig. 3c), revealed that the yield of 3A5AF steadily increased with the reaction time at 120 °C, peaking at 26.4 % after 180 min, albeit significantly lower than the yields achieved at the other three reaction temperatures. At 130 °C and 140 °C, the yield of 3A5AF initially rose and subsequently declined, achieving a maximum of 55.2 % at 140 °C after 60 min. This decrease in yield was attributed to the onset of side reactions and, subsequently, the decomposition of 3A5AF [41]. When the temperature was escalated to 150 °C, the yield of 3A5AF reached a peak value of 51.4 % within a shorter duration of 30 min, followed by a decreasing trend. This indicated that prolonged reaction times at higher temperatures may induce product decomposition and the formation of humic substances [23], further highlighting the mutual synergism and influence between reaction temperature and time. Moreover, substrate concentration stands as another significant factor influencing the yield of 3A5AF. As exhibited in (Fig. 3d), the yield of 3A5AF ascended to 60.3 % at a substrate concentration of 75 mM. However, with the subsequent increase in substrate concentration, the yield of 3A5AF exhibited a decreasing trend, dropping to 46.9 % at 175 mM. This elevation in substrate concentration may lead to the production of substantial amounts of humic substances, while intermolecular interactions could diminish the selectivity towards 3A5AF. These findings resonate with the observations reported by Padovan et al. [22]. 3.3 Recycling of catalysts and solvents The recycling of catalysts and solvents represents a fundamental requirement within the field of green chemistry [19]. The results are shown in Fig. 4 , the reaction solution after the reaction under the optimal reaction conditions was treated and the catalyst and solvent were recycled four times. The quantitative HPLC analysis of the reaction solution revealed that the yield of 3A5AF decreased from 60.3 % to 49.9 %. The catalytic activity of the catalyst was maintained above 80 %, which indicated that the reuse of the catalytic system was feasible. The observed decline in product yield can be attributed primarily to the exceptional mutual solubility between DMA and water encountered during the recovery and extraction processes. Rotary evaporation proved insufficient for complete removal of residual water from DMA. Given the sensitivity of the catalytic system to water, this residual moisture adversely affects the dehydration reaction of N-acetyl-D-glucosamine (NAG), potentially promoting undesirable side reactions and consequently diminishing product selectivity [23]. Furthermore, a minor fraction of the catalyst is lost through dissolution in ethyl acetate during extraction. Since the experimental protocol did not include replenishment with fresh catalyst, this dissolution loss represents an additional plausible factor contributing to the reduced yield of 3-acetamido-5-acetylfuran (3A5AF) [40]. Moreover, because of its low solubility in DMA (as shown in Fig. 1a), NH4Cl cannot be completely dissolved. Nevertheless, it can be recovered using filtration and recycled, thus reducing the waste of resources. 3.4 Isolation and purification of the product To obtain pure 3A5AF with high purity, the compound within the reaction solution was isolated and purified via low-temperature crystallization, as detailed in the Experimental section. The precipitated crystals exhibited a needle-shaped or feather-like morphology under microscopic observation (shown in Fig. S7(a) and (b)). Following filtration, washing, and drying, the crystals underwent NMR analysis for structural confirmation and purity assessment (Figs. S8 and S9). Furthermore, HPLC analysis (Fig. S10) revealed peaks exclusively corresponding to 3A5AF, corroborating the product's purity. This crystallization method proved simpler and yielded a purer product (99 %) compared to traditional column chromatography purification [38]. Subsequent separation and purification experiments yielded dried 3A5AF crystals. Based on mass measurements, the isolated yield was calculated as 45.8 %, lower than the actual reaction yield (60.3 %). This discrepancy is likely attributable to physical losses incurred during separation and crystallization. For instance, incomplete extraction during the separation step may leave product within the aqueous phase or mother liquor. To mitigate this, the mother liquor can be collected for repeated extraction and crystallization cycles. Further optimization of the isolation and purification protocol is warranted to minimize product loss and resource wastage. 3.5 Exploring possible reaction paths 3.5.1 NMR spectra To explore possible reaction paths, 1H NMR and 13C NMR were carried out on the reaction solution at 140 °C for varying reaction times. For a more intuitive comparison of results, the 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of pure N-Acetyl-Glucosamine (NAG) were utilized as a control group. The outcomes of the 1H NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 5 ) revealed that the signals corresponding to NAG (at 4.42 ppm, 4.61 ppm, and 4.92 ppm) were notably weak at the 2-minute mark, suggesting its rapid consumption. Furthermore, a novel signal emerging at 6.29 ppm between 5 and 30 min was presumably attributed to an intermediate, which nearly vanished by the 60-minute mark. Concurrently, signals associated with 3A5AF, specifically at 7.29 ppm and 8.20 ppm, became detectable at the 10-minute mark and progressively intensified over time, indicating an increase in NAG concentration. This gradual signal enhancement is indicative of a concentration increase. The results of the 13C NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 6 ) demonstrated the appearance of new signals at 67 ppm, 102 ppm, 131 ppm, and 155 ppm at the 10-minute reaction interval. These signals exhibited a significant decrease in intensity at the 30-minute mark and completely disappeared by the 60-minute mark, leading to the presumption that they belonged to the signals of intermediates b and c. Notably, the characteristic peak signals of intermediate d were absent from the 13C NMR spectral results, suggesting its potential classification within intermediates b and c. The absence of intermediate d's signals in the 13C NMR spectra, coupled with the assumption of its low concentration, indicated that the primary intermediates facilitating the conversion of NAG to 3A5AF in this system were intermediates b and c. In contrast to 1H NMR, the signals corresponding to 3A5AF in the 13C NMR spectra were not detectable until the 30-minute mark, likely due to the low concentration in the reaction solution sample at the 10-minute mark. 3.5.2 LC-MS technology for the analysis of key intermediates and products LC-MS technology possesses notable advantages, including high sensitivity and efficient separation capabilities. To gain further insights into the critical intermediates and products involved in a specific chemical reaction, the reaction solutions obtained at various time points during the reaction conducted at 140 °C were subjected to LC-MS (analysis in both positive and negative ion modes. The results, as depicted in (Fig. S11), revealed that when the reaction progressed for 2 min, peak A, with a retention time of 1.03 min, was identified as the raw material NAG (m/z=256, negative ion mode). This peak showed a significant decrease in intensity by 5 min. Concurrently, characteristic peak B (retention time of 1.41 min, m/z=202, negative ion mode), which is postulated to belong to the key intermediate b, was detected. For additional verification, the reaction solutions collected between 5 and 15 min were analysed using the positive ion mode of LC-MS. The results, illustrated in (Fig. 7 ), indicated that the characteristic peak C of intermediate b (retention time approximately 1.0 min, m/z=204, positive ion mode) was also observed at 5 min. Furthermore, the characteristic peak D of another potential intermediate, either c or d, was detected (retention time approximately 1.7 min, m/z=186, positive ion mode). Notably, the signal intensity of the characteristic peak F (of 3A5AF (retention time approximately 4.8 min, m/z=168, positive ion mode) gradually increased with the prolongation of the reaction time up to 15 min. This observation suggests an increase in the concentration of the intermediate, which is gradually converted to 3A5AF. Additionally, the characteristic peak E was identified as originating from the solvent DMA (retention time 1.89 min, m/z=88, positive ion mode). 3.5.3 Plausible reaction pathways Two primary molecular mechanisms have been reported in the literature for the conversion from NAG to 3A5AF. Firstly, Wang et, al. proposed that the open-chain aldehyde of NAG undergoes ring closure and isomerization to form a furan-ring intermediate, which subsequently dehydrates to yield 3A5AF [18]. Alternatively, Guo et, al. suggested a different dehydration pathway, wherein the open-chain aldehyde of NAG initially loses one H2O molecule, followed by ring closure to form the intermediate Chromogen I. Further removal of two molecules of H2O from Chromogen I results in the formation of 3A5AF [42]. Upon analysing the outcomes of LC-MS and NMR spectroscopic analyses, we posit that the probable reaction pathway in this catalytic system for the NAG-to-3A5AF conversion aligns more closely with the first mechanism, as illustrated in (Scheme 1 ). In this scheme, the release of Cl- ions from MgCl2 and NH4Cl triggers the breakage of hydrogen bonds in NAG, converting it into an open-chain aldehyde form [9]. Consequently, the lone electron pair on the -OH oxygen atom at the C4 position attacks the C atom of the aldehyde group, leading to ring closure and forming a furan-ring structure. The solution adopts a weakly acidic environment due to the H+ ions generated from the dissociation of NH4 + from NH4Cl, facilitating the dehydration of the five-membered cyclic intermediate to produce intermediate a. Under acidic conditions, the H atom of the -OH group of the alkenyl alcohol moiety in intermediate a exhibits acidic property. The H atom of the -OH group of the enol form of intermediate a becomes protonated and undergoes intramolecular rearrangement (keto-enol isomerization) to afford intermediate b. Intermediates c or d, formed through dehydration of intermediate b, undergo further dehydration to yield 3A5AF ultimately. In addition to the dominant catalytic role of the anionic Cl⁻ in the dehydration of NAG, Mg2+ may exhibit a chelating effect analogous to that of Ca2+ in biomass conversion processes. Such chelation could facilitate spatial proximity between functional groups (e.g., amide and hydroxyl groups) within NAG, thereby promoting a more compact transition state configuration and consequently lowering the reaction activation energy. Thus, Mg2+ may potentially serve an auxiliary role to Cl⁻, effectively promoting the reaction progression [43]. Future catalyst selection strategies should extend beyond anions alone, aiming to discover more efficient systems leveraging synergistic anion-cation interactions. In the future, our choice of catalysts should not be limited to anions, but to discover more efficient catalysts in which anions and cations synergize with each other. 4 Conclusions In this study, the cost-effective and readily accessible chloride salt MgCl2 emerged as the optimal chloride salt catalyst, attributed to its high solubility at 140 °C in polar aprotic solvent DMA, as well as its favorable solubilizing effect on NAG. Additionally, ammonium salts were demonstrated to be potent additives, with NH4Cl exhibiting the highest efficacy when compared to other ammonium salts. In contrast to most of the previous research, the impact of the catalytic system on the yield of 3A5AF was primarily examined at lower temperatures (≤150 °C). The optimization of crucial parameters, encompassing catalyst dosage, temperature, reaction time, and substrate concentration, led to a 3A5AF yield of 60.3 % under optimal reaction conditions. Notably, the catalytic system was reused and recycled without the need for additional catalysts or any specific treatment. After four cycles, its catalytic activity remained above 80 %. Ultimately, the potential reaction intermediates were deduced through LC-MS and NMR spectral analysis, and plausible reaction pathways were proposed. In conclusion, this study demonstrates that 3A5AF can be produced in good yield under mild conditions with an inexpensive catalyst. By avoiding the high energy demand of traditional high-temperature routes, the protocol expands the low-temperature repertoire for chitin-to-3A5AF conversion and underscores the untapped potential of chitin biorefineries for nitrogen-containing fine chemicals. It delivers a simple, green, and energy-frugal pathway that is readily scalable. Future efforts should focus on two complementary priorities: (i) developing low-boiling, environmentally benign organic solvent systems that enable both energy-efficient solvent recovery and high-yield 3A5AF production at reduced temperatures, and (ii) discovering and designing new catalysts that integrate robust dehydration activity with cooperative cation–anion effects, ensuring optimal catalyst–solvent–substrate matching to drive chitin valorisation toward greener, milder, and more productive regimes. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of high-value organic nitrogen compounds from renewable chitin biomass presents significant environmental advantages by reducing reliance on fossil resources. Among these compounds, 3-acetamido-5-acetylfuran (3A5AF) has emerged as a versatile nitrogen-containing platform molecule, attracting extensive research attention. However, existing studies indicate that 3A5AF formation in polar aprotic solvents (e.g., N, N-dimethylacetamide, DMA) typically requires harsh conditions (>150 °C), likely due to limited catalyst and substrate solubility at lower temperatures. To address this challenge, this study employed anhydrous magnesium chloride (MgCl₂) as a catalyst—selected for its Cl⁻ supply capacity based on solubility tests—combined with ammonium salts as additives to establish a weakly acidic reaction environment. The catalytic system enabled efficient 3A5AF conversion under milder conditions, achieving a remarkable yield of 60.3% at 140 °C. This research provides a low-energy, economic and easy-to-industrialize technological path for the preparation of nitrogen-containing fine chemicals from chitin biomass.

coredata.dc:title: A chloride-mediated low-energy pathway for selective 3A5AF production from N-acetylglucosamine via solubility-tailored catalysis
